underexposed.meaning: Insufficiently exposed for proper or full development, as negatives in photography.

undergarment.meaning: A garment to be worn under the ordinary outer garments.

underman.meaning: To equip with less than the full complement of men.

undersell.meaning: To sell at a lower price than.

undersized.meaning: Of less than the customary size.

underlie.meaning: To be the ground or support of.

undermine.meaning: To subvert in an underhand way.

understate.meaning: To fail to put strongly enough, as a case.

underwrite.meaning: To issue or be party to the issue of a policy of insurance.

undulate.meaning: To move like a wave or in waves.

unguent.meaning: Any ointment or lubricant for local application.

unique.meaning: Being the only one of its kind.

unison.meaning: A condition of perfect agreement and accord.

unisonant.meaning: Being in a condition of perfect agreement and accord.

Unitarian.meaning: Pertaining to a religious body that rejects the doctrine of the Trinity.

unwieldy.meaning: Moved or managed with difficulty, as from great size or awkward shape.

upheaval.meaning: Overthrow or violent disturbance of established order or condition.

upheave.meaning: To raise or lift with effort.

urban.meaning: Of, or pertaining to, or like a city.

usurious.meaning: Taking unlawful or exorbitant interest on money loaned.

usurp.meaning: To take possession of by force.

usury.meaning: The demanding for the use of money as a loan, a rate of interest beyond what is allowed by law.

utilitarianism.meaning: The ethical doctrine that actions are right because they are useful or of beneficial tendency.

utility.meaning: Fitness for some desirable practical purpose.

vaccinate.meaning: To inoculate with vaccine virus or virus of cowpox.

vacuum.meaning: A space entirely devoid of matter.

vale.meaning: Level or low land between hills.

valedictorian.meaning: Student who delivers an address at graduating exercises of an educational institution.

vapid.meaning: Having lost sparkling quality and flavor.

variant.meaning: A thing that differs from another in form only, being the same in essence or substance.

variegate.meaning: To mark with different shades or colors.

vegetarian.meaning: One who believes in the theory that man's food should be exclusively vegetable.

vegetate.meaning: To live in a monotonous, passive way without exercise of the mental faculties.

vegetative.meaning: Pertaining to the process of plant-life.

venereal.meaning: Pertaining to or proceeding from sexual intercourse.

venial.meaning: That may be pardoned or forgiven, a forgivable sin.

venom.meaning: The poisonous fluid that certain animals secrete.

venous.meaning: Of, pertaining to, or contained or carried in a vein or veins.

veracious.meaning: Habitually disposed to speak the truth.

verbiage.meaning: Use of many words without necessity.

verification.meaning: The act of proving to be true, exact, or accurate.

verify.meaning: To prove to be true, exact, or accurate.

vernal.meaning: Belonging to or suggestive of the spring.

versatile.meaning: Having an aptitude for applying oneself to new and varied tasks or to various subjects.

version.meaning: A description or report of something as modified by one's character or opinion.

vertical.meaning: Lying or directed perpendicularly to the horizon.

vestige.meaning: A visible trace, mark, or impression, of something absent, lost, or gone.

veto.meaning: The constitutional right in a chief executive of refusing to approve an enactment.

vicarious.meaning: Suffered or done in place of or for the sake of another.

viceroy.meaning: A ruler acting with royal authority in place of the sovereign in a colony or province.

vicissitude.meaning: A change, especially a complete change, of condition or circumstances, as of fortune.

vigilance.meaning: Alert and intent mental watchfulness in guarding against danger.

vigilant.meaning: Being on the alert to discover and ward off danger or insure safety.

vignette.meaning: A picture having a background or that is shaded off gradually.

vindicate.meaning: To prove true, right, or real.

viol.meaning: A stringed instrument of the violin class.

viola.meaning: A musical instrument somewhat larger than a violin.

violoncello.meaning: A stringed instrument held between the player's knees.

virtual.meaning: Being in essence or effect, but not in form or appearance.

virtuoso.meaning: A master in the technique of some particular fine art.

visage.meaning: The face, countenance, or look of a person.

viscount.meaning: In England, a title of nobility, ranking fourth in the order of British peerage.

visualize.meaning: To give pictorial vividness to a mental representation.

vitality.meaning: The state or quality of being necessary to existence or continuance.

vitalize.meaning: To endow with life or energy.

vivisection.meaning: The dissection of a living animal.

vocable.meaning: a word, especially one regarded in relation merely to its qualities of sound.

vocative.meaning: Of or pertaining to the act of calling.

vociferance.meaning: The quality of making a clamor.

vociferate.meaning: To utter with a loud and vehement voice.

volition.meaning: An act or exercise of will.

voluptuous.meaning: having fullness of beautiful form, as a woman, with or without sensuous or sensual quality.

voracious.meaning: Eating with greediness or in very large quantities.

vortex.meaning: A mass of rotating or whirling fluid, especially when sucked spirally toward the center.

votary.meaning: Consecrated by a vow or promise.

vulgarity.meaning: Lack of refinement in conduct or speech.

waive.meaning: To relinquish, especially temporarily, as a right or claim.

wampum.meaning: Beads strung on threads, formerly used among the American Indians as currency.

wane.meaning: To diminish in size and brilliancy.

wean.meaning: To transfer (the young) from dependence on mother's milk to another form of nourishment.

well-doer.meaning: A performer of moral and social duties.

whereabouts.meaning: The place in or near which a person or thing is.

whet.meaning: To make more keen or eager.

wield.meaning: To use, control, or manage, as a weapon, or instrument, especially with full command.

wile.meaning: An act or a means of cunning deception.

witling.meaning: A person who has little understanding.

witticism.meaning: A witty, brilliant, or original saying or sentiment.

wizen.meaning: To become or cause to become withered or dry.

working-man.meaning: One who earns his bread by manual labor.

workmanlike.meaning: Like or befitting a skilled workman.

workmanship.meaning: The art or skill of a workman.

wrangle.meaning: To maintain by noisy argument or dispute.

wreak.meaning: To inflict, as a revenge or punishment.

wrest.meaning: To pull or force away by or as by violent twisting or wringing.

writhe.meaning: To twist the body, face, or limbs or as in pain or distress.

writing.meaning: The act or art of tracing or inscribing on a surface letters or ideographs.

wry.meaning: Deviating from that which is proper or right.

yearling.meaning: A young animal past its first year and not yet two years old.

zealot.meaning: One who espouses a cause or pursues an object in an immoderately partisan manner.

zeitgeist.meaning: The intellectual and moral tendencies that characterize any age or epoch.

zenith.meaning: The culminating-point of prosperity, influence, or greatness.

zodiac.meaning: An imaginary belt encircling the heavens within which are the larger planets.
